STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ELIZABETH HERTEL
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
March 8, 2022
Suzanne Lewis
Catholic Charities of Jackson, Lenawee & Hillsdale
199 N. Broad Street
Adrian, MI 49221
RE: License #: CB460308844
Catholic Charities of Jackson, Lenawee & Hillsdale
425 Ormsby
Adrian, MI 49221
Dear Ms. Lewis:
Attached is the Interim Report for the above referenced facility completed on 2/16/2022.
Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, sections of the contract and Modified
Settlement Agreement (MISEP) requirements, a written corrective action plan is required.
It should be noted that violations of any licensing rules are also violations of the MISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved. For repeat violations,
please indicate why the prior CAP was unsuccessful and what changes will
be made to ensure compliance going forward.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or MISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager, Jessica VandenHeuvel, (616) 204-6992.
Sincerely,
Heather Reilly, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
22 Center Street
Ypsilanti, MI 48198
(734) 660-8309
enclosure
2

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules except
for the following:
R 400.12306 Application request.
(4) An agency shall document that the licensee has been given
an application for renewal of the license not less than 60
calendar days before the expiration date of the license.
Two of three licensing files did not meet this requirement. Both files documented
the application was sent within 60 days of the license expiration. Through
discussion it was determined the agency misunderstood the wording of this rule.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an MISEP violation. Please note that there
are additional MISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1. The facility
is in compliance with all additional MISEP requirements.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a MDHHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional MDHHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance with all additional MDHHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
FOM 801-03 Medical passports
Page 2
All medical information within the medical passport must be
current and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's
current and complete health information.
Two of eight foster care files did not have quarterly updated medical passports
with signatures.
File one: A quarterly update did not occur between June 2021 and January 2022.
File two: A quarterly update did not occur between February 2021 and July 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
12/29/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/19/2021
3/24/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/15/20
FOM 722-06 B Family Team Meeting
Page 5
Case Plan Development/Reassessment: Updated Case Plan
(USP) - within 30 calendar days before the case plan due date.
Placement Preservation/Disruption: At least three business days
prior to a planned change of placement or no later than three
business days after an unplanned placement change.
4

Seven of eight foster care files did not meet this requirement.
File one: An FTM and 1105 report were not completed within 30 days prior to the
9/7/21 USP.
File two and three: FTMs and 1105 reports were not completed for the USPs
dated 4/30/21, 7/29/21 and 1/25/22.
File four: FTMs and 1105 reports were not completed for USPs dated 5/11/21 and
8/4/21.
File five: FTMs and 1105 reports were not completed for USPs dated 3/15/21,
8/30/21 and 11/18/21.
File six: FTMs and 1105 reports were not completed for USPs dated 3/4/21 and
6/2/21.
File seven: An FTM did not occur for a youth’s move in November 2021.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
12/29/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/19/2021
FOM 722-06H Case Contacts
Page 19
The caseworker must enter the required face-to-face contacts
listed below in MISACWIS within five business days of the
contact. This includes attempted and missed face-to-face
contacts.
Seven of eight foster care files held contacts that were not entered into
MiSACWIS within the required timeframe.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
12/29/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/19/2021
3/24/20 INTERIM, CAP approved 4/15/20
FOM 722-08 Case Service Plans- Overview, Types, and Timeframes
Page 11
The supervisor must approve all case service plans within 14
days of the end of the report period.
One of eight foster care files held a USP that was approved one day late. The
10/27/21 USP was approved on 11/11/21.
FOM 722-08D Treatment Plans
Page 10
The caseworker must obtain signatures from all applicable
individuals and upload the signatures pages into the electronic
case record within 30 days of the report date.
5

Five of eight foster care files held PATPs that did not meet this requirement.
File one & two: The 4/30/21 PATP was signed late by a parent on 6/2/21, the
other parent on 6/11/2, and the foster parent on 6/15/21. The 7/29/21 PATP was
signed late by a parent on 9/9/21. The 10/27/21 PATP was signed late by a
parent on 12/16/21.
File three: The 12/29/21 PATP was signed late by the youth and foster parent on
1/31/22.
File four: The 3/4/21 PATP was signed late by the foster parent on 4/21/21. The
11/17/21 PATP was signed late by the foster parent on 12/21/21.
File five: The 11/24/21 PATP was signed late by a parent and foster parent on
1/4/22.
FOM 801-01 Health Requirements
Page 4
A dental re-examination shall be obtained at least every six
months unless a greater frequency is indicated.
One of eight foster care files held a late dental. A six-month dental re-examination
was due in August 2021, but it was not completed until November 2021.
FOM 722-08E Foster Care/Juvenile Justice Action Summary
Page 3, Page
6
Placement Change: Prior to a planned placement change, or
within three business days of an emergency placement change,
the caseworker must document…
Case closure: Within three business days of foster care and/or
juvenile justice program/case closure, the caseworker must
document…
One of eight open files and one of two closed files held late action summaries.
File one (open): The youth moved on 11/29/21; the DHHS 69 was completed late
on 12/6/21.
File two (closed): The case closed on 12/10/21; the DHHS 69 was not completed
until 12/22/21.
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED:
12/29/2020 RENEWAL, CAP approved 1/19/2021
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
 Foster home license renewals- the application must be provided at least 60
days before the expiration date of the license. The agency must document it
was provided at least 60 days before the license expiration. It was clarified
the agency could provide it more than 60 days in advance of the expiration.
 PATPs must be signed and dated within 30 days of the report date. This is
the date the report was completed not the date the report was approved. A
signature date is required to verify the document was signed on time.
6

 Clarification was provided that Family Team Meetings are required within 30
days prior to the service plan due date (FOM 722-06B).
V. CONSULTATION
The agency did not require consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There were no incidents of substantiated child abuse or neglect during this
licensing period.
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
On 9/9/21 a special evaluation was initiated due to an allegation that a foster child
was spanked. An investigation was completed and the foster family found in violation
of 9404(3) Behavior Management. A Corrective Action Plan was signed by the foster
parents on 12/14/21. The CAP included training “Discipline vs. Punishment: The
Difference In Child Development”, increased monthly contact with the foster parent
by the licensing supervisor, case management assessment of behavior at monthly
foster home visits, and ongoing input with the child’s therapist about concerns or
behavior management techniques if needed. The CAP was completed on 2/9/22.
The foster parents are in compliance at this time, but the agency will continue to
monitor behavior management in this home.
The agency submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related to
maltreatment during this licensing period.
The CAP, approved 1/19/2021, was a result of the 12/29/2020 renewal evaluation in
which the agency had fifteen violations. During this interim review, the agency had
eight violations. However, four of the eight were repeat violations. The agency
acknowledged in the Chief Administrator Assessment that they struggled in these
four areas due to staffing issues. During the review, the agency was receptive to
suggestions in each of these areas and had several ideas for a CAP. Overall, the
agency showed improvement in several areas during this interim review.
Chief Administrator Assessment
The Chief Administrator Assessment, dated 9/30/21, was reviewed and discussed.
The agency reported successfully implementing the CAP from their 2021 renewal
evaluation. Administration adjusted areas throughout the year, where the original
was not as effective as originally anticipated. Supervisors continue to monitor
performance data to determine how CAP adjustments have performed. The program
manager reported that policy clarification training, additional tracking of due dates,
implementation of new forms, and utilizing case aids in new ways, has all been
helpful over this past year. However, it was also noted that the agency still struggles
with timely entry of case contacts, signatures on PATPs, and medical passports. The
Administrator reported the Monthly Management Report shows the agency performs
well with service plan due dates, medical/dental exams, and supervision. The MMR
also shows the agency needs improvement on face-to-face contacts. The
7

Administrator stated that was likely due to some staffing struggles they faced this
past year. Staffing was challenging at times due to significant growth in the program.
As well as absences due to COVID. The agency reported staffing has improved at
this time.
Staff interviews
Contact occurred with agency licensing and foster care supervisors, and one foster
care worker. All staff reported feeling the agency was a supportive, positive work
environment. All staff stated they have good relationships with co-workers and
managers. The FCW stated their supervisor is accessible, helpful, knowledgeable,
and responsive. Staff acknowledged that court in one particular county can be
challenging at times. However, there were no other concerns reported.
VII. ANALYST FINDINGS
There were no identified safety concerns.
VIII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules, MISEP requirements, or contract/policy. Upon receipt
of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that the facility continue
on a regular license.
March 8, 2022
Heather Reilly Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
March 8, 2022
________________________________________
Jessica VandenHeuvel Date
Area Manager
8
